The description says "you will only select the resource pile with the most resource points currently available, regardless of its future value". However, in the case of ties, the required tiebreaker is the rate, which is effectively equivalent to its immediate future value.

import bisect
import collections

turns = int(input())
data = collections.defaultdict(list)
for _ in range(int(input())):
    value, rate = [int(i) for i in input().split()]
    bisect.insort(data[value], rate)
wait = [None] * 4
cycle = 0

points = 0
best = None
for _ in range(turns):
    insert = wait[cycle]
    if insert is not None:
        value, rate = insert
        if best is not None and value > best:
            best = value
        bisect.insort(data[value], rate)
    if data:
        if best is None:
            best = max(data)
        points += best
        rate = data[best].pop()
        wait[cycle] = (best * rate // 100, rate)
        if not data[best]:
            del data[best]
            best = None
    else:
        wait[cycle] = None
    cycle = (cycle + 1) % 4

print(points)

As written, there's a major flaw in this puzzle, in that the greedy solution doesn't always come up with the best answer. For example, consider this input:
5
4
50 100
100 10
100 10
100 10
It would be advantageous to pick the first item in the first round, so that it will be available again in the last round, earning 400. However, the greedy algorithm only collects 360 in total.

import math

k = int(input())
v = [list(map(int, input().split()))for _ in range(int(input()))]

t = 0
a = {}
for i in range(k):
    if str(i) in a:
        v_value = a.pop(str(i))
        v += [[math.floor(v_value[0]*v_value[1]/100), v_value[1]]]
    if v:
        v_max = max(v)
        t += v_max[0]
        a[str(i+4)] = v.pop(v.index(v_max))
     
print(t)

1. Fixed the wrong floor division, thank you and cedricdd for both pointing it out. I fixed his second comment but not the first when I last altered this.

2. Optimisation would be to alter the array to remove redundant values. Given an array with 1 million values all with 100 replenish - You would only need the largest 4 as they would be the only values used and replenished. Given a list of variable replenish rates, you need the largest 4 with 100 replenish and any with less than 100 replenish with a value greater than the minimum with 100.
